titleStmt.author: Virginia Woolf

msIdentifier.repository: Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection of English and American Literature

physDesc.p: M1-8, 9 of 10. The Reader. In back [Articles, essays, fiction and reviews], vol. 8 [1938-39], pp. 34-36. 3p.

handNote.p: Holograph writing by the documents' main hand, Virginia Woolf

correction.p: Apparent errors have been explicitly corrected in sic / corr tags, wrapped in a choice element.

interpretation.p: Names and references to places and literary works have been wrapped in rs tags which link to annotations and secondary material.

projectDesc.p: Text encoded as part of 'The Digital "Anon": A Digital Genetic Edition of Virginia Woolf's Final Essays'. This project, funded by Leverhulme Grant ECF-2022-602, seeks to construct a TEI-XML based digital edition of the drafts of 'Anon' and 'The Reader', among the final documents Woolf wrote before her death.

div.p: We can suppose that the reader reading public came into existence some four hundred years ago; when the playhouse could no longer hold the play. But he was when the play outgrew the playhouse; when the playhouse was shut. But he was the to & was brought into being by came into existence when in the first place the playhouse was h shut; & when the plays outgrew the theatre. & in the second theatre the play became outgrew the theatre. & cd. (could) only be realised fully if read But the reading public must have a small one: a r recruited [compared?] from a the scholars & aristocrats. The lack of general wider spread common reading explains accounts for the long pause, between death & the 18th century when the plays of Shakespeare hang suspended, unrealised. They had to wait until the plays were in m on open on many private tables, in many palms of hands, before they received the other life, which the detailed, the particular life which that the reader confers. This Again, it accounts for scarcity of Ethan (Elizabethan) criticism, & the general nature of what criticism there is. Both & deal with the general Both Sidney & Jonson are deal with the theory of poetry or of drama not with the particular play or poem; the attention which task [thus?] both Sidney & Jonson [dwell?] are concerned with general functions, of the nature of poetry & drama such as occur to the trained writer; & not w writing about matters that interest for writers; not with the particular the critic there is no the critic was not in the concerned with explain They are not

p.sup: & cd. (could) only be realised fully if read.

div.p: curious of any a duty owed to the general public; for the public has is as yet making no asking no questions rather a asking then for information; either about the play, or the playwright, for instance, for the general public s had to draw in the play as they stood or st sat at the playhouse, through their earsor through the eye. They could not deepen & service these impressions at a table in a private room. & thus [We?] that a book of the words by [illeg.] they could not ask the kind of question which was to call forth our a profession in our day is debated answered in every day in the newspapers.

p.s: Much that was lost in the playhouse was discovered when the play was read in the private room – the criticism of the past hundred years has has added to the common understanding of . But much was also lost for ever when the playhouse shut: the sound of his spoken word; the what the

p.sup: So far the Elizabethan drama is concerned

the To The profits & losses of this account are difficult to settle – on the one hand, the habit of brought into existence much that could only be discovered in the private room: , , to name some to take some of the obvious names, who have been reading into existence, during the past 200 years – has increased our understanding. But much was lost for ever when the playhouse shut we have lost the sound of the spoken word: all that l an individual [lushe?] & bloom, an those in a physical quality, in E (Elizabethan) language

He is the writer in embryo: capable that is of all the impulses of a writer, save only that he cannot as give his exteriorise his emotions; but but cannot in give them shape; & this emotion is as the & his influence upon what is written is must be prodigous; it [unrelated?]

It was to this [illeg.] & blind infant, & the [illeg.] on his hands in the glare of the
E (Elizabethan) playhouse & [fly?] away weary from its potential that we owe the Elizabethan words – & a book like the , for example: that very anxious, still half born, half born book: a book that is still amorphous: neither one thing or another; a book that the writer cannot control, because the reader is not yet able to read; a book that flops, flounders, is now all [exchanges?] & [illeg.], yet has so [being?] as (Shakespearean) words;
